NEWS BITES

Homeownership Among Latinos Rises in U.S., Racial Disparities Remain Pervasive Rates of homeownership among Latino buyers are exceeding those of overall buyers in the U.S., helping to narrow the racial gaps in homeownership. Significant pay and wealth disparities greatly impact the rates of homebuying, and the ownership gap has only edged up slightly in the past five years. Latino communities were more deeply impacted by foreclosures during the years between 2007 and 2015. World Property Journal

U.K. New Home Demand Hits Six-Year Low Demand for new homes in the U.K. is continuing to slip, falling 8% in the last year to hit a six-year low, according to the Federation of Master Builders, as potential buyers choose to wait until there is more clarity in the Brexit situation before they commit to anything. Firms dealing in small-home building report the demand has fallen to 2.9 out of 5 (compared to 3.14 last year), and they foresee further declines that could take the number down to 2.75. City A.M.

Singapore Sees Rental Prices Slip Rental prices in Singapore dipped in September from the month prior. Rates for condos fell 0.4%, though they rose 3.2% year-over-year. Compared to the high seen in 2013, rental prices were 16.9% below the high they hit in January of 2013. Rents in Singapore’s central area decreased the most, falling 1.1%, while those at the city edges fell by 0.2% and those in the suburbs by 0.1%. Business Times

New Hong Kong Development Discounts Unit Prices Hong Kong developer CK Asset Holdings, the region’s second biggest, is dropping prices on its latest project by up to 10%, as ongoing government protests continue to insert uncertainty into the real estate market. The 876-home development, which is set to be finished in June of 2021, is located in a New Kowloon suburb, and the prices are 10.4% below a newly launched project from Henderson Land Development that’s located nearby. South China Morning Post

Former New York Home of Judge Judy Lists for $11.75 Million The former New York City home of Judith Sheindlin, TV’s Judge Judy, has hit the market for $11.75 million, which is close to twice what she originally paid. Ms. Sheindlin bought the 3,160-square-foot two-bedroom, which is located in the Sherry-Netherland Hotel and looks out onto both Central Park and Fifth Avenue, in 2009 for $6.75 million, and sold it for $8.5 million four years later. New York Post

Westwood, Los Angeles, is Most Expensive Place to Rent in California California’s highest rents can be found in Westwood, where prices, which rose 4.1% from last year, averaged $4,944 per month, according to a report from RentCafe. The neighborhood, which is home to UCLA, is the fourth most expensive area in the U.S., following three New York City neighborhoods. RentCafe’s list of the 50 priciest ZIP Codes included 18 from California, six of which were in the Los Angeles area, and 12 of which were from the San Francisco Bay Area. Los Angeles Times
